moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 c6 3. e3 Nf6 4. Nc3 g6: Major choice point: I chose the Grunfeld (Schlecter var) over the Semi-Slav. I am more comfortable with Fiancettos in general.
moves.5. h3 Bg7 6. Nf3 O-O 7. b3 Qa5 8. Bd2 Qc: Things started getting a little tight from this point. I desperately needed to free my queenside Knight and the Bishop.
moves.11... c5 12. d5 e6 13. dxe6 Bxe6 14. O-O: Saw a brief attack opportunity against a file of bishops
moves.15. Qc2 a6: This was intended to deny 16. Nb5 which I thought would cause me some serious problems.
moves.16. Ne2 Nc6 17. Bc3 a5: Not sure why I did this instead of Nb4. I might have been greedy to try and gain an open a-file and move the a pawn to the b file. Perhaps I was not keen on "demoting" the c pawn to the b file.
moves.18. Rfd1 Nb4 19. Bxb4 axb4 20. Nf4 Ra6 2: I believe I had to continually remind myself about the possibility of a back-rank mate from this point on. It looks defensible but I was worried about sac-combos that might force critical defending pieces away.
moves.23... Ra3: Looked like I had strong forcing sequences here, but it fizzled out after a few moves.
moves.24. Qc2 Rc3 25. Qe2 Rxc1 26. Rxc1 Qd6: Had a small advantage at this point, I think. My main targets were the two isolated pawns. I was trying to keep him on the defensive so he cannot move his knight and bishop out into more effective locations.
moves.27. Bc2: Strong move. (on hindsight) Allows Bb3 to secure the 2 pawns and also Rd1 for the attack.
moves.27... Qa6 28. Bb3: On hindsight, I should have foreseen Bb3 and done something more useful instead of giving him a free tempo.
I was looking to continue to dominate that black diagonal to cover h2.
moves.35. Nd5 Nc3: This move probably sealed the eventual draw.
moves.36. Nxc3 bxc3: Am wondering if I should have taken with the bishop instead. I was gunning for Qd2 which more or less forces an advantageous exchange of queens but he obviously saw it coming.
moves.37. Qd3 Qxd3: I believe the reason I did this was because I did not want him controlling the d file. Perhaps Ke6 might have been better since if he goes for the exchange, I can take with the king and that's where I'd really want him anyways. Guess I was also worried about the 4 vs 3 pawn structures on the king-side.
moves.38. Bxd3 Kf6 39. Kf1 h5: Sensing that he wanted to move his king to attack the queen-side (would take a while), I had two options - move my own king over (takes even longer) or mount a pawn attack on the king-side with the king and bishop for support. Note that his bishop is strong as long as I keep my pawns on white squares, so my imperative was to do a "dark side" attack, hehe.
moves.40. Ke2 g5 41. f3 f4 42. e4 g4: A calculated risk. I hadn't really expected this would cause a draw, but I had hoped he would over-reach with an attack and allow a win on my part.
moves.43. fxg4 hxg4 44. hxg4 Kg5 45. Kf3 Kh4: I offered a draw at this point, but was declined. My plan was to convince him by toggling the king until I see his plan.
moves.46. Bc2 Kg5 47. Bd1:
Now, this move scared me *after* I made my move. I reacted (which is bad in a correspondence game) by simply toggling.

I realized if he posted his bishop at f3, it allows his king the freedom to march queen-side. My king could march over to shore up the position, but I was not 100% sure I could safely handle the two pass-pawns on the e and g files with just my bishop.
moves.47... Kh4 48. Kf2 Kg5 49. Kg1: Apparently he did not see Bf3 or had some other idea.
moves.49... Kh4 50. Kf2: Draw was offered at this point. He left a nice concessionary message to which I failed to respond to (because I did not notice it prior to accepting the draw and gameknot closes the comments interface after the game closes), for which (if he reads this) I am very sorry for. Meant to say "Good game".
